Material used.Description: CHO cells were transfected with pZeoSV2 full-length WT, L10P, L166P, or P158DEL human DJ-1 constructs.

Readout description.Result Description: L10P DJ-1 exhibited reduced stability and was significantly destabilized compared to WT DJ-1.
P158DEL DJ-1 exhibited reduced stability and was significantly destabilized compared to WT DJ-1.
L166P DJ-1 exhibited reduced stability and was significantly destabilized compared to WT DJ-1.

Technical replicates.Description: Each sample was run in triplicate.

Basic positive control.Description: Wild-type DJ-1 was used as a positive control.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: Two-way ANOVA and Bonferroni’s post hoc test

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: Protein stability comparable to WT DJ-1.

Threshold for abnormal readout.Threshold for abnormal readout: Protein stability significantly reduced compared to WT DJ-1.

Experiment Method.Assay Method: Co-immunoprecipitation and heterodimer or homodimer analysis

Material used.Description: CHO cells were co-transfected with N-terminal HA-tagged full-length WT human DJ-1 construct and pZeoSV2 full-length untagged WT, L10P, L166P, or P158DEL human DJ-1 constructs.

Readout description.Result Description: L10P DJ-1 retained the ability to dimerize with WT DJ-1 but was unable to form homodimers.
P158DEL DJ-1 retained the ability to dimerize with WT DJ-1 but was unable to form homodimers.
L166P DJ-1 was not co-immunoprecipitated with HA-tagged WT DJ-1 and was unable to form homodimers.

Technical replicates.Description: Each sample was run in triplicate.

Basic positive control.Description: Wild-type DJ-1 was used as a positive control.

Basic negative control.Description: Empty vector was used as a negative control.

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: Proper dimerization with WT DJ-1 and homodimer formation.

Threshold for abnormal readout.Threshold for abnormal readout: Impaired dimerization with WT DJ-1 and inability to form homodimers.

Material used.Description: CHO cells were transfected with full-length WT, L10P, L166P, or P158DEL human DJ-1 pZeoSV2 (+) constructs.

Readout description.Result Description: L10P DJ-1 exhibited an apparent elution profile consistent with a slightly larger conformation than WT protein, despite the finding that it cannot homodimize.
P158DEL DJ-1 exhibited an elution profile indicating that it is natively smaller than WT protein, suggesting that it may be predominantly monomeric.
L166P DJ-1 formed high-molecular-weight complexes and was deficient in the ability to form homodimers.

Biological replicates.Description: Experiments were repeated at least 3 times.

Technical replicates.Description: Each sample was run in triplicate.

Basic positive control.Description: Wild-type DJ-1 was used as a positive control.

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: Elution profile consistent with dimer formation.

Threshold for abnormal readout.Threshold for abnormal readout: Elution profile indicating altered structural conformations.

Material used.Description: CHO cells were transfected with full-length WT, L10P, L166P, or P158DEL human DJ-1 pZeoSV2 (+) constructs.

Readout description.Result Description: L10P DJ-1 demonstrated reduced solubilities, particularly evident following treatments with MG-132 or epoxomicin.
P158DEL DJ-1 demonstrated reduced solubilities under native conditions, but proteasome inhibition did not enhance the accumulation of insoluble species.
L166P DJ-1 demonstrated dramatic accumulations of insoluble proteins following treatments with MG-132 or epoxomicin.

Technical replicates.Description: Each sample was run in triplicate.

Basic positive control.Description: Wild-type DJ-1 was used as a positive control.

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: Protein solubility comparable to WT DJ-1.

Threshold for abnormal readout.Threshold for abnormal readout: Reduced solubility and accumulation of insoluble proteins.

Material used.Description: CHO cells were transfected with full-length WT, L10P, L166P, or P158DEL human DJ-1 pZeoSV2 (+) constructs.

Readout description.Result Description: L10P DJ-1 formed intracellular inclusions following proteasome inhibition, particularly evident in 84±13% of cells treated with MG-132.
P158DEL DJ-1 formed intracellular inclusions following proteasome inhibition, particularly evident in 68±11% of cells treated with MG-132.
L166P DJ-1 formed intracellular inclusions following proteasome inhibition, particularly evident in 49±10% of cells treated with MG-132.

Technical replicates.Description: Each sample was run in triplicate.

Basic positive control.Description: Wild-type DJ-1 was used as a positive control.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: Two-way ANOVA and Bonferroni’s post hoc test

Material used.Description: CHO cells stably expressing WT or L10P DJ-1 were generated.

Readout description.Result Description: L10P DJ-1 was unable to rescue CHO cells under proteasome stress conditions and was toxic, leading to significantly reduced viabilities.

Technical replicates.Description: Each sample was run in triplicate.

Basic positive control.Description: Wild-type DJ-1 was used as a positive control.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: Two-way ANOVA and Bonferroni’s post hoc test
